title: How should I make my criticism constructive? - Quora

response.answer_text: I was once told that criticism is never constructive! It's just a fancy name for pointing fingers and fault finding. ie “Why do YOU (always) ? “ deliberately shifts the focus off of the accuser. Sometimes it means that the accuser then rightly or wrongly, And sometimes it may even mean that accuser dosnt accept any responsibility or accountability for what happens. Ie” it's them alone to blame, and I DO blame THEM”. Thus he beholds the speck in the OTHERs eye, not realizing he has a bolt in his own eye. To want to HELP someone to see something, or see it differently, or understand the error of their ways is only constructive so long as it is builds or contributes to the other person's development or future advancement. Never is it done to manipulate or control someone else that WE have judged. Therefore, largely it the MOTIVE that is important. The first group wants to break down, accuse and destroy or even annihilate or obliterate. Often one finds this in that “cat eats mouse”, awful game of politics where it's all about the survival of the fittest and how it affects the campaigner, and even it means huring the opponents it is considered legitimate in that they feel that the end justifies the means. So what I was told was that if you really think about it, “constructive criticism” is actually a contradiction in terms. (One word contradicts the other) . It's either criticism (negative) …or it's constructive admonition which would be helpful advice that aims to build up and not to destroy. The other aspect is that we CORRECT someone because we care about them, and so sometimes we DO need to say something that may not be popular so that they can be helped out of a rut, saved from future damage, protected from hurtful people or situations, or stopped from making a fool of themselves. In this case, NOT to say something would be deeply unloving and uncaring. In the Bible there is a scripture that says I am my brothers keeper…or something to that effect. So especially if it's another believer, he DOES become our responsibility especially since, if I see my brother sinning…by my keeping quiet, it may mean my brother falls into error or even goes away from God. So since have a responsibility to God, as His mouthpiece.. I speak out when something is unfair or unjust., evil destructive or in Godly. (as the saying goes ”All it takes for evil to prosper, is for good men to say nothing “) In this instance ALL is based on my commitment to Christ, and since I love Him, living my life to serve HIM, I love my brother (even if he's slipped up) realizing full well that it could well have been me who was affected. The motivation here then is to redeem my brother so that He can be fully restored.

One of the powerful skills for a manager is to give a feedback to his team or employees. Feedback is when one person communicates their observations to another. The manager should give feedback to: ✔ Let the employees know if they are doing a task correctly, to standard. ✔ Let the employee know what they need to do to improve performance. ✔ Build the employee's confidence. ✔ Increase the employee's motivation. How to give an " Effective Feedback". ▶ Be specific. + Clearly describe your observations; don't judge. + When providing constructive criticism, clearly describe the "desired state." + When providing positive feedback tell the associate specifically what he/ she did well, so that the associate knows what to repeat in the future. ▶ Be considerate. + Make sure the employees can get something out of what you are telling them, that will help them improve poor performance or repeat good performance. +Pick a good time to share your feedback. Speak so that other associates/ employees don't overhear your conversation. Remain calm, using conversational language, tone & geatures. ▶ Be timely. + Talk to the employee immediately, when you observe it. ▶ State why. + Describe the impact; why it is important. ▶ Ask questions/check. + Ask, if you need additional information. Make sure the employee understand what you are saying. These are few tips that will help all the managers/ Supervisors give an effective feedback and improve and build a positive relationship with their employees.

It is extremely important that you criticize the behavior, not the person. Call no names. Never say “you always….” Keep any emotions you feel totally out, like frustration and or anger. These are going to have no effect at all or are going to turn the person off. So point out exactly what the wrong behaviors were and point out the correct ones. What you are doing is teaching, not finding fault or assessing blame. “It might be better if you…” “Try this way….” “Let’s see that move again and I’ll show you what’s wrong with it.” “I have learned that….” and so on. So, be soft, not dictatorial. Think army sergeants and do the opposite.
Simple… Don’t tell someone what they are doing wrong… Tell them how to do it better.  “How should I make my criticism constructive?”

Constructive criticism is made helpful by the sandwich method. Introduction, criticism, compliment. Eg: “This may sound like I'm judging but I'm not. It might be helpful. This project will most likely fail because of X Y and Z. But I'm glad for the interest in the project as well. So was I. Use “I messages” not “you messages” (blame). Keep the focus on the issue not on the person.

I always like to serve a criticism sandwich. Start by mentioning something positive, the the “meat” of what can be improved, and then end with something positive. Another approach is to not criticize unless you can offer an alternative. So don’t tell someone they are doing something wrong unless you can suggest another way that they can go about it.

The best way to give constructive criticism would be to stick to the truth without deviations. Unfortunately, this is not possible in this era of pretending to be what you are not. “If we tell the truth, we fail our ethical obligation. If we fulfill our ethical obligation, we are not telling the truth.”

Letting the focus shift from any comparison/parallel standpoints of views to focus ever more on getting to the very core-roots-fundamentals to help establish a more mature/enhanced and ever realistic understanding. For if we just skimp through the surfaces-there might be a lot underneath that keeps getting precariously overlooked? and might tend to confront us further ahead at in’stances’ and in ever more unimaginable ways…….

People do not like to receive criticism, that’s part of life. However, if you want to offer criticism; constructive criticism. Perhaps, you can try these ways. Commendation, recommendation; That means to say something nice then followed by constructive criticism. Criticise and then something nice. People usually switch off if they know you are critical in your comment.

I think it begins with a few simple but very important pieces…be mindful of the timing when giving the cc. Be mindful of your tone when giving cc. Focus on the task/situation instead of the person. Have you heard of the “Feedback Sandwich”? Look it up..it’s a great approach and I’ve always been successful when I practiced it. And always keep in mind, always consider, how you would appreciate hearing constructive criticism. Good luck.

Most times it's appreciated, do this away from anyone's ear. It's not what you say, rather how you say it. Keep your voice level. If they begin to get uncomfortable simply tell them you care and are trying to help.

Privately, without trying to make yourself look good in front of others. And in such a way that its to build the other person not tear them down. If you're saying it to get something off your chest…you are doing it for selfish reasons.
By offering it as behaviour you practise as well. If it's an act you find less than decent walk the offender through why someone may find what done disagreeable. People have all sorts of blindspots
Be positive about the good things someone accomplished first. Then , diplomatically, detail the not so great things. Tempercyour criticism with humor . That always helps.
Don’t focus on what you think is wrong; focus on how the person could improve what they are doing, and express it kindly.
